Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2012 04:53AM HLB wrote: My doc is stingy about ativan too. When I was first dx with mets he did give me a scrip and it was 1mg 3x a day. I thought geez I don't need that much! Well I ran out and I wasn't ok so I called the nurse coordinator and it turned out he was on vacay, so she got another doc to write it and she put 4 refills on it thank God! I take one a day most of the time, sometimes 2. I think you have to experiment because it affects people differently. A friend of mine took a half mg before oral surgery and I picked him up afterwards and he was so messed up he peed his pants. It doesn't make me act weird at all. Sometimes I fall asleep but sometimes I don't. I can tell when I need one because I get short of breath. I don't get worried about addiction either. My goal is a happy like with no stress or anxiety. Whatever it takes. Anxiety and stress is not good for our cancer.

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2013 05:54AM HLB wrote: I wondered a lot about this myself; why my bone mets were not being radiated so we could do like caryn said, kill the buggers. It seems to me that its assumed I won't be cured so we save the rads for when I need them, like if they become painful. However, I think if the mets are limited, like if you only have 2, some people think its worth it to treat aggressivly to go for a possible cure, or at least a long time ned. I think I would look into another opinion just to see what they say. There's a guy at U of FL in Gainsville who is doing SBRT for 10 or less lesions going for the cure. It sounds like a really good treatment and there's a video on youtube all about it. His name is Paul Okenuiff (sp) Okunieff(?). I have all the info and keeping it on the back burner. I also would wonder like someone said above, why do the rads to the breast now that it has spread. It seems like its either backwards or maybe both sould be done...or no rads at all. Anyway about that sbRT, its very precise to the point where you get 5-10 tx instead of 30. The machine moves with your breathing and everything. Its called a VERO machine. At the time I was looking into it there were only 2 VERO, one in Gainsville and one in Jacksonville. He thinks people with limited mets should at least be given a chance at cure and he wants to change the definition of what is considered incurable. In the video there's a guy who had lung cancer, about 8 lesions I think. He was NED 8 years after getting the treatment. Don't know if he still is but heck 8 years after lung ca is pretty amazing.

Mom has a friend who is also my friend who is a very nice lady but a bit of a meddler, always trying to bring people together. Tried to hook me up with her step son years ago. Now she's trying to hook me up with her hairdresser who recently finished tx for a lower stage breast ca. I said she's welsome to call me if she wants to but really, I would not want to if I was her. Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2013 08:21AM HLB wrote: The one in houston is supposed to be the best and a lot of ladies go there as well as their own local onc and they work together. This is such a scary blow but I would look at this way, there are not that many leaions except the lungs which just says numerous. A friend of mine recently had a big shocker like this; she had 2 small lung mets which resolved quicly on femara and stayed that way for about 2 years. About two weeks after her most recent good scan that was showing everything good, she started getting dizzy. Had another scan and all of a sudden there were mets in brain, lung, liver, bones, and lymph nodes! She had wbr and the brain is completely resolved. Switched to faslodex and everything else is resolved except one or two lymph nodes. When you get the right treatment it doesn't seem to matter how bad it seems. She doesn't even have any late effects of the wbr. I would definitely check into MDA or at least a 2nd opinion somewhere, just to see what more than one dr thinks should be done.

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2013 08:56PM HLB wrote: I haven't read this whole thread so sorry if I'm repeating anything. This is how to be prepared for chemo: if you are having a limited number of treatments (4 or 8) scedule them all in advance to make sure there's an opening on your day of the week and a better chance of getting the time you want. At the first one, take a tablet and write down what time treatment started. Then write in it for the rest of the day whatever you are feeling, what meds you took, what you ate etc, all with the time of day it happened. This really helped me because I took the anti nausea med that night at the time they told me to, and 45 min later I felt sick for hours til I finally slept. The next time I took it one hour earlier and never felt sick again. Its good to keep the diary for the first few days because you can refer back to it to see how things went on the 2nd and 3rd day and so on. If there were any issues the nurses usually had suggestions.

Posts.Content: May 26, 2016 10:58PM HLB wrote: I just saw this thread so I thought I would share my experience. Been on xgeva for 4 yrs now every month with no signs of stopping or reducing according to onc. I had extreme fatigue with the first 2 or 3 shots for one day, and after that no noticable SE. I recently had a root canal/crown with no problems. My onc says this drug prevent cancer from growing. I am a little concerned about the long term effects I asked him about 2 years ago if I should go to every other month but he said no. He's very big on this drug. There is an oral care protocol I found about that I experimented with for 6 month now. You can find it by searching for "Dr Ellie". My last cleaning went well and was slightly improved from the last one. What I didn't tell them was that during those 6 months I hardly ever flossed! That is part of the protocol, that you don't need to floss and she thinks it can damage gums, but I will go back to flossing anyway now the experiment is over. Basically you do this morning and night: rinse with Closys, brush with Crest Anticavity (no glycerin), rinse with Listerine, then rinse with Act..05 percent flouride. Then you eat zylitol mints or gum throughout the day, esp after eating.

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2012 01:06PM HLB wrote: I was very depressed and anxious when I got my bmx. I had to wait an extra 2 hours because an emergency came in and that made it worse because I had that time to think about what was going to happen and I had black magic marker on my boobs. I was sobbing the whole way into the OR and it really pissed me off because it was not neccesary and my poor parents were with me and had to see me so upset. Anyway, the point I wanted to make was that after the surgery was done it never bothered me! I recovered normally and had no problems with the way I looked (I did have expanders and tiny mounds afterwards). I was afraid to take the bandages off and my mom and I stood in front of the mirror and took them off, worried about what we would see! We both had the same reaction and were like, wow, that doesn't look bad at all! So I guess what I'm saying is take your ativan and try not to worry, when its over things get better. I used to never even take a tylenol. Now my motto is just say yes to drugs! Its not healthy to have anxiety, physically or mentally, and the ativan really does work. Good luck to you with your surgery!

The whole thing was very organized and non frustrating compared to what I'm used to. There is no income requirement for the lodge, you just get to stay and you can also have a caregiver stay with you. Unfortunately it was a short time before new bone Mets popped up, the ones that were treated are pretty much guaranteed to not come back, unlike regular rads that are mostly for pain reduction. The only problem I can think of is that one lesion might be a little bit too big, but I don't remember the exact cutoff. I have pic of doctor Okunieff in my cubicle. He is my hero for actually caring and being willing to try! For most of us we won't be cured, but there's always a few lucky ones. He cured a man of lung cancer who was completely given up on. Last time I saw his video he was 8 years from the treatment. If you search his name on YouTube there's a few videos.Â  Good luck at the 2nd opinion. If they are unwilling to send you to an IR I would do a search for them and call them yourself!

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2012 09:04AM HLB wrote: I have thought about this issue almost to the point of mental turmoil. I know there is no cure, but should I be doing more? Probably not. I think most of my anguish is coming from not being sure that I am on the same page with my onc. He is an excellent and very highly esteemed onc, but he seems to want to make the point about no cure just a little bit too much for my liking, always using the word palliation. I'm keeping an open mind until I see him at least once more, but I may go for another opinion. I'm not comfortable with the fact that we do a treatment until progression, then do another one. I want to have treatment that works BEFORE progression is found, rather than just wait for it! Maybe that's not realistic and doesn't make a difference, but I want to keep this confined if at all possible and sometimes I feel like since we can't be cured, the oncs just take their good old time about things figuring we are going to die anyway. I'm just not sure yet if that is my oncs thinking or not. We will see. He does do the ca27-29 for early stage even though its not recommended because he disagrees with the thinking that it won't prolong life. That is good because my mets were found before I had any symptoms. But now that I'm there, is he giving up so to speak? Not asking for an answer, just thinking out loud.

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2012 10:47PM HLB wrote: Hi, the way month onc explained dose dense was thet when you get a chemo tx, it starts killing cancer cells, and I think at some point in the cycle it is at its peak, killing lots of cancer, then gradually slows down. As its slowing down, the cancer cells not killed yet start dividing, so by getting a tx 2 weeks later instead of 3, you can get those cells quicker and they have less time to grow. So if you can tolerate it, dose dense is better. I was achey from the neulasta but nothing unbearable. Everyone is different but I wouldn't assume you will have a lot of pain. I do exhaustive research to the point of being ridiculous, and I remember being scared to death of Taxol based on what I read. When I finally had it it was a cakewalk compared to AC! Not that it was pleasant of course. When I had the first tx of AC and the se's kicked in, I said oh my god, how am I goingto one more let alone 3! But when I had the first taxol I said hey, this is doable!

They make my essiac tea, get me carrot juice, send me info that they find that might help, always want to go to appts with me etc. I'm doing ok so far since I don't have any symptoms. I really hope they don't ever have to go through seeing me debilitated. Emotionally I don't really have anyone except all of you here. There's certain things we just don't talk about or consider, for example dying. I'm fine with that because I don't want to consider it. We just go with the assumption that everything will be ok. I'm with the poster above who likes the bed to herself. I don't like sharing my space or my time!

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2012 07:54PM HLB wrote: I agree with everyone...raise some hell! I would explain to whoever what that nurse said to you and DEMAND something to take for anxiety, as well as getting put on a list for cancellation. That's a horrible feeling and to have it for a month is just unacceptable. Now, as for the mass, she cannot tell if it is malignant. My surgeon thought for sure that mine was not so she excised it instead of biopsy because she didn't want to shoot that gun too close to my lungs. Well sure enough, it was cancer. And I consider her to be the best breast surgeon in the world! So try not to let that nurse get to you. I know it easier said than done. I'm sitting here getting pissed at her more and more. Who would do that to a person!! And nurses are supposed to be compassionate. Geez. Anyway, most lumps are not cancer. If it is, try to just remember the worst that can happen is you get it removed, get yout treatments, and get cured! I remember being so terrified that I would die young and when I got more educated and realized that was not going to happen I calmed down a lot. Then I got organized and did what I had to do! I pray for good results for you. Hang in there.
